plain_language_layer_name: USDA-identified Prime Farmland
source_data_title: Gridded Soil Survey Geographic (gSSURGO) Database
source_data_description: The gSSURGO Database is derived from the official Soil Survey Geographic (SSURGO) Database. SSURGO generally has the most detailed level of soil geographic data developed by the National Cooperative Soil Survey (NCSS) in accordance with NCSS mapping standards. The tabular data represent the soil attributes and are derived from properties and characteristics stored in the National Soil Information System (NASIS).
source_data_citation: Soil Survey Staff. Gridded Soil Survey Geographic (gSSURGO) Database for the Conterminous United States. United States Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service. Available online at https://gdg.sc.egov.usda.gov/. September 25, 2023 (202210 official release).
layer_methodology: The gSSURGO data is in the form of a geodatabase where features must be mapped to a survey raster before being exported as as shapefile. The Farmland Classification data is found under the Land Classifications SDV folder in the dataset. This data is mapped to the 30m survey raster before being downscaled to the 1000m gridcerf resolution. For the prime farmland layer, the following gSSURGO classification is used: All areas are prime farmland - "Prime farmland is land that has the best combination of physical and chemical characteristics for producing food, feed, forage, fiber, and oilseed crops, and is also available for these uses (the land could be cropland, pastureland, rangeland, forest land, or other land, but not urban built-up land or water)."
source_data_title_check: Gridded Soil Survey Geographic (gSSURGO) Database

United States Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service. Available online at https://gdg.sc.egov.usda.gov/. September 25, 2023 (202210 official release).
layer_methodology: The gSSURGO data is in the form of a geodatabase where features must be mapped to a survey raster before being exported as as shapefile. The Farmland Classification data is found under the Land Classifications SDV folder in the dataset. This data is mapped to the 30m survey raster before being downscaled to the 1000m gridcerf resolution. For the farmland of local importance layer, the following gSSURGO classification is used: Farmland of state importance - In some local areas there is concern for certain additional farmlands for the production of food, feed, fiber, forage, and oilseed crops, even though these lands are not identified as having national or statewide importance. Where appropriate, these lands are to be identified by the local agency or agencies concerned.

plain_language_layer_name: Contiguous US Land Area
source_data_title: Cartographic Boundary Files - Shapefile
source_data_description: The cartographic boundary files are simplified representations of selected geographic areas from the Census Bureau's MAF/TIGER geographic database. These boundary files are specifically designed for small scale thematic mapping.The cartographic boundary files are available in shapefile and KML format. A shapefile is a geospatial data format for use in geographic information system (GIS) software. For KML versions of these files, please see our Cartographic Boundary Files - KML page.
source_data_citation: US Census Bureau, 2018. Cartographic Boundary Files - Shapefile. https://www2.census.gov/geo/tiger/GENZ2018/shp/cb_2018_us_state_5m.zip (accessed 10/12/23)
layer_methodology: The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization. All land areas are given a burn value of 0, all non-land areas are given a burn value of 1. No other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Proximity to Surface Flow Greater than 2 MGD, 20km buffer
source_data_title: Surface Water Flow
source_data_description: This data is a representation of stream and river water bodies derived from the National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) and is symbolized by flow rate from gauge adjusted values from the USGS Extended Unit Runoff Method(EROM) table. The EROM table contains other mean annual flow/velocity statistics for the NHDFlowline features such as Flow from runoff or Velocity from runoff. Subject matter experts on this data agreed that for the purposes of finding flow discharge rates of cooling water for power plants, the gauge adjusted vales were the ideal empirical values for this study. It should also be noted that the flow rates were originally in Cubic feet per second (cfs) but converted to Gallons per minute (gpm). The geospatial data sets included in NHDPlusV2 are intended to support a variety of water- related applications. They already have been used in an application to develop estimates of mean annual streamflow and velocity for each NHDFlowline feature in the conterminous United States. The results of these analyses are included with the NHDPlusV2 data. A water-quality model developed by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) called SPARROW (Spatially Referenced Regressions on Watershed Attributes), can utilize the NHDPlusV2 network functionality to track the downstream transport of nutrients, sediments, or other substances. NHDPlusV2 water bodies and estimates of streamflow and velocity are used in SPARROW to identify reservoir retention and in-stream loss factors. NHDPlusV2 climatic and land surface attributes can be used in SPARROW to identify potential factors in the delivery of nutrients from the land surface to streams. NHDPlusV2 data is also being used in select areas for a USGS Web-based application, called StreamStats. StreamStats provides tools to interactively select any point in the implemented areas, delineate watersheds, and to obtain streamflow and watershed characteristics for the selected point. NHDPlusV2 has been designed to accommodate many users' needs for future applications. NHDPlusV2 provides the framework and tools necessary to customize the behavior of the network relationships as well as building upon the attribute database, for which the user can assign their own data to the network.
source_data_citation: Moore, R. B. et al. User's guide for the national hydrography dataset plus (NHDPlus) high resolution: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2019–1096. https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/ofr20191096 (2019).
layer_methodology: Thermoelectric power plants that draw water from natural surface water sources are only permitted to draw water from sources that meet minimum surface water flow thresholds corresponding to the amount of gallons withdrawn by the plant. The surface water flow data is used to create suitability layers corresponding to a 20km region around surface water sources that meet the corresponding MGD threshold. The source dataset was reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization.

NHDPlusV2 water bodies and estimates of streamflow and velocity are used in SPARROW to identify reservoir retention and in-stream loss factors. NHDPlusV2 climatic and land surface attributes can be used in SPARROW to identify potential factors in the delivery of nutrients from the land surface to streams. NHDPlusV2 data is also being used in select areas for a USGS Web-based application, called StreamStats. StreamStats provides tools to interactively select any point in the implemented areas, delineate watersheds, and to obtain streamflow and watershed characteristics for the selected point. NHDPlusV2 has been designed to accommodate many users' needs for future applications. NHDPlusV2 provides the framework and tools necessary to customize the behavior of the network relationships as well as building upon the attribute database, for which the user can assign their own data to the network.
source_data_citation_check: Moore, R. B. et al. User's guide for the national hydrography dataset plus (NHDPlus) high resolution: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2019–1096. https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/ofr20191096 (2019).

plain_language_layer_name: Proximity to Surface Flow Greater than 25 MGD, 20km buffer
source_data_title: Surface Water Flow
source_data_description: This data is a representation of stream and river water bodies derived from the National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) and is symbolized by flow rate from gauge adjusted values from the USGS Extended Unit Runoff Method(EROM) table. The EROM table contains other mean annual flow/velocity statistics for the NHDFlowline features such as Flow from runoff or Velocity from runoff. Subject matter experts on this data agreed that for the purposes of finding flow discharge rates of cooling water for power plants, the gauge adjusted vales were the ideal empirical values for this study. It should also be noted that the flow rates were originally in Cubic feet per second (cfs) but converted to Gallons per minute (gpm). The geospatial data sets included in NHDPlusV2 are intended to support a variety of water- related applications. They already have been used in an application to develop estimates of mean annual streamflow and velocity for each NHDFlowline feature in the conterminous United States. The results of these analyses are included with the NHDPlusV2 data. A water-quality model developed by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) called SPARROW (Spatially Referenced Regressions on Watershed Attributes), can utilize the NHDPlusV2 network functionality to track the downstream transport of nutrients, sediments, or other substances. NHDPlusV2 water bodies and estimates of streamflow and velocity are used in SPARROW to identify reservoir retention and in-stream loss factors. NHDPlusV2 has been designed to accommodate many users' needs for future applications. NHDPlusV2 provides the framework and tools necessary to customize the behavior of the network relationships as well as building upon the attribute database, for which the user can assign their own data to the network.

plain_language_layer_name: Proximity to Surface Flow Greater than 95 MGD, 20km buffer
source_data_title: Surface Water Flow
source_data_description: This data is a representation of stream and river water bodies derived from the National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) and is symbolized by flow rate from gauge adjusted values from the USGS Extended Unit Runoff Method(EROM) table. The EROM table contains other mean annual flow/velocity statistics for the NHDFlowline features such as Flow from runoff or Velocity from runoff. Subject matter experts on this data agreed that for the purposes of finding flow discharge rates of cooling water for power plants, the gauge adjusted vales were the ideal empirical values for this study. It should also be noted that the flow rates were originally in Cubic feet per second (cfs) but converted to Gallons per minute (gpm). The geospatial data sets included in NHDPlusV2 are intended to support a variety of water- related applications. They already have been used in an application to develop estimates of mean annual streamflow and velocity for each NHDFlowline feature in the conterminous United States. The results of these analyses are included with the NHDPlusV2 data. A water-quality model developed by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) called SPARROW (Spatially Referenced Regressions on Watershed Attributes), can utilize the NHDPlusV2 network functionality to track the downstream transport of nutrients, sediments, or other substances. NHDPlusV2 water bodies and estimates of streamflow and velocity are used in SPARROW to identify reservoir retention and in-stream loss factors. NHDPlusV2 climatic and land surface attributes can be used in SPARROW to identify potential factors in the delivery of nutrients from the land surface to streams. NHDPlusV2 data is also being used in select areas for a USGS Web-based application, called StreamStats. StreamStats provides tools to interactively select any point in the implemented areas, delineate watersheds, and to obtain streamflow and watershed characteristics for the selected point. NHDPlusV2 has been designed to accommodate many users' needs for future applications. NHDPlusV2 provides the framework and tools necessary to customize the behavior of the network relationships as well as building upon the attribute database, for which the user can assign their own data to the network.
source_data_citation: Moore, R. B. et al. User's guide for the national hydrography dataset plus (NHDPlus) high resolution: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2019–1096. https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/ofr20191096 (2019).
layer_methodology: Thermoelectric power plants that draw water from natural surface water sources are only permitted to draw water from sources that meet minimum surface water flow thresholds corresponding to the amount of gallons withdrawn by the plant. The surface water flow data is used to create suitability layers corresponding to a 20km region around surface water sources that meet the corresponding MGD threshold. The source dataset was reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization.

source_data_description: This data is a representation of stream and river water bodies derived from the National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) and is symbolized by flow rate from gauge adjusted values from the USGS Extended Unit Runoff Method(EROM) table. The EROM table contains other mean annual flow/velocity statistics for the NHDFlowline features such as Flow from runoff or Velocity from runoff. Subject matter experts on this data agreed that for the purposes of finding flow discharge rates of cooling water for power plants, the gauge adjusted vales were the ideal empirical values for this study. It should also be noted that the flow rates were originally in Cubic feet per second (cfs) but converted to Gallons per minute (gpm). The geospatial data sets included in NHDPlusV2 are intended to support a variety of water- related applications. They already have been used in an application to develop estimates of mean annual streamflow and velocity for each NHDFlowline feature in the conterminous United States. The results of these analyses are included with the NHDPlusV2 data. A water-quality model developed by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) called SPARROW (Spatially Referenced Regressions on Watershed Attributes), can utilize the NHDPlusV2 network functionality to track the downstream transport of nutrients, sediments, or other substances. NHDPlusV2 water bodies and estimates of streamflow and velocity are used in SPARROW to identify reservoir retention and in-stream loss factors. NHDPlusV2 climatic and land surface attributes can be used in SPARROW to identify potential factors in the delivery of nutrients from the land surface to streams. NHDPlusV2 data is also being used in select areas for a USGS Web-based application, called StreamStats. StreamStats provides tools to interactively select any point in the implemented areas, delineate watersheds, and to obtain streamflow and watershed characteristics for the selected point. NHDPlusV2 has been designed to accommodate many users' needs for future applications. NHDPlusV2 provides the framework and tools necessary to customize the behavior of the network relationships as well as building upon the attribute database, for which the user can assign their own data to the network.
source_data_citation: Moore, R. B. et al. User's guide for the national hydrography dataset plus (NHDPlus) high resolution: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2019–1096. https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/ofr20191096 (2019).
layer_methodology: Thermoelectric power plants that draw water from natural surface water sources are only permitted to draw water from sources that meet minimum surface water flow thresholds corresponding to the amount of gallons withdrawn by the plant. The surface water flow data is used to create suitability layers corresponding to a 20km region around surface water sources that meet the corresponding MGD threshold. The source dataset was reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization.

A water-quality model developed by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) called SPARROW (Spatially Referenced Regressions on Watershed Attributes), can utilize the NHDPlusV2 network functionality to track the downstream transport of nutrients, sediments, or other substances. NHDPlusV2 water bodies and estimates of streamflow and velocity are used in SPARROW to identify reservoir retention and in-stream loss factors. NHDPlusV2 climatic and land surface attributes can be used in SPARROW to identify potential factors in the delivery of nutrients from the land surface to streams. NHDPlusV2 data is also being used in select areas for a USGS Web-based application, called StreamStats. StreamStats provides tools to interactively select any point in the implemented areas, delineate watersheds, and to obtain streamflow and watershed characteristics for the selected point. NHDPlusV2 has been designed to accommodate many users' needs for future applications. NHDPlusV2 provides the framework and tools necessary to customize the behavior of the network relationships as well as building upon the attribute database, for which the user can assign their own data to the network.
source_data_citation: Moore, R. B. et al. User's guide for the national hydrography dataset plus (NHDPlus) high resolution: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2019–1096. https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/ofr20191096 (2019).

plain_language_layer_name: Offshore Areas Coastline Buffer (20 mile)
source_data_title: 2022 TIGER/Line Shapefiles: Coastline
source_data_description: The 2022 TIGER/Line Shapefiles contain current geographic extent and boundaries of both legal and statistical entities (which have no governmental standing) for the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the Island areas. This vintage includes boundaries of governmental units that match the data from the surveys that use 2022 geography (e.g., the 2022 American Community Survey).
source_data_citation: US Census Bureau, 2022. TIGER/Line Shapefiles: Coastline. Geography Division, U.S. Census Bureau, https://www2.census.gov/geo/tiger/TIGER2022/COASTLINE/tl_2022_us_coastline.zip
layer_methodology: All coastal areas + a 20 mile buffer are used to create the coastline suitability layer. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Offshore Danger Zones and Restricted Areas
source_data_title: Danger Zones and Restricted Areas
source_data_description: These data represent the location of Danger Zones and Restricted Areas within coastal and marine waters, as outlined by the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) and the Raster Navigational Charts (RNC). The CFR defines a Danger Zone as, "A defined water area (or areas) used for target practice, bombing, rocket firing or other especially hazardous operations, normally for the armed forces. The danger zones may be closed to the public on a full-time or intermittent basis, as stated in the regulations." The CFR defines a Restricted Area as, "A defined water area for the purpose of prohibiting or limiting public access to the area. Restricted areas generally provide security for Government property and/or protection to the public from the risks of damage or injury arising from the Government's use of that area." Other features in this dataset include: Danger Area, Missile Testing Area, Naval Operations Area, Prohibited Area, Restricted Airspace, Test Area, and Torpedo Testing Area. Authoritative information relating to these data may be found in Title 33, Chapter II of the CFR (Part 334).
source_data_citation: Office for Coastal Management, 2023. Danger Zones and Restricted Areas. NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information, https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/inport/item/48876.
layer_methodology: All areas in the dataset are included in the compiled suitability layer. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003)coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Offshore Habitat Areas of Particular Concern
source_data_title: Habitat Areas of Particular Concern
source_data_description: The purpose of HAPCs is to focus conservation, management, and research efforts on subsets of EFH that are vulnerable to degradation or are especially important ecologically for federally managed fish. The HAPC designation alone does not confer additional protection or restrictions to an area, but helps to focus EFH conservation, management, and research priorities. HAPC designation is a valuable way to acknowledge areas where we have detailed information on ecological function and habitat vulnerability, indicating a greater need for conservation and management. In some instances the Councils and NMFS may develop fishery management measures to conserve the habitat within the HAPC.
source_data_citation: NOAA, 2023: Habitat Areas of Particular Concern. National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration, https://marinecadastre-noaa.hub.arcgis.com/datasets/noaa::habitat-areas-of-particular-concern/about
layer_methodology: All habitat areas are included in the GRIDCERF suitability layer. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Offshore National Marine Sanctuaries
source_data_title: National Marine Sanctuary Program Digital Boundary Files
source_data_description: The Office of National Marine Sanctuaries manages a system of sanctuaries and other managed areas around the country. The legal boundaries of these sanctuaries are defined within the Code of Federal Regulations, at 15 C.F.R. Part 922 and the subparts for each national marine sanctuary. The GIS compatible digital boundary files for each national marine sanctuary are representations of those legal boundaries and are based on the best available data. These files are available for public use at locations defined in this metadata record.
source_data_citation: NOAA / National Marine Sanctuaries Program. National Marine Sanctuary Program Digital Boundary Files. NOAA/National Marine Sanctuaries Program, Silver Spring, Maryland. https://sanctuaries.noaa.gov/library/imast_gis.html (accessed 09/22/23).
layer_methodology: The following marine sanctuaries are included in the composite suitability layer: Channel Islands, Cordell Bank, Florida Keys, Flower Garden Banks, Gray's Reef, Greater Farallones, Mallows Bay-Potomac River, Monitor, Monterey Bay, Olympic Coast, Stellwagen Bank, Thunder Bay, Wisconsin Shipwreck. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003)coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Offshore Munitions and Explosives of Concern
source_data_title: Munitions and Explosives of Concern
source_data_description: Munitions and explosives of concern (MEC) have been deposited on the seabed of the United States Outer Continental Shelf since World War I. The bulk of these munitions have originated from the U.S. Armed Forces while conducting military training exercises, war-time placement, and disposal and dumping activities. Since 1972, ocean disposal of munitions and other pollutants has been banned by the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act. Federal and state efforts to mitigate, map, monitor, and sometimes remove these munitions are ongoing. The term MEC defines a collection of munitions including a) unexploded ordnance, b) discarded military munitions, and c) munition constituents that are present in high enough concentrations to pose an explosive hazard.
source_data_citation: Office for Coastal Management, 2023: Munitions and Explosives of Concern NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information, https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/inport/item/69013.
layer_methodology: All areas in the dataset are included in the compiled suitability layer. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003)coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Offshore Outer Continental Shelf Areas Withdrawn from Leasing
source_data_title: Outer Continental Shelf Areas Withdrawn from Leasing
source_data_description: These data represent areas that are permanently or temporarily withdrawn from oil, gas, renewable, critical mineral, or sand leasing or some combination of these by various authorities, including the Gulf of Mexico Security Act of 2006, presidential withdrawals under Sec. 12 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act, 43 U.S.C. Sec. 1341, or the National Marine Sanctuaries Act, 16 U.S.C. Sec. 1431-1434, 33 U.S.C. 1401 et seq. Additionally, some marine national monuments within the area under BOEM's leasing authority include language that restricts certain types of leases.
source_data_citation: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management - Office of Strategic Resouces, 2021: BOEM Outer Continental Shelf Areas Withdrawn from Leasing. Departement of Interior - Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, https://www.boem.gov/oil-gas-energy/leasing/boemocsareas-withdrawn-leasing-2021.zip
layer_methodology: For the GRIDCERF suitability layer, only excluded areas that are applicable to renewable energy development ('ORSM', 'ORM') and those that are permanently excluded are added to the exclusion area used. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Offshore Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones
source_data_title: Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones for US waters
source_data_description: The automatic identification system (AIS) is a navigation safety device that transmits and monitors the location and characteristics of many vessels in U.S. and international waters in real time. In the U.S., the Coast Guard and industry collect AIS data, which can also be used for a variety of coastal planning purposes. NOAA and BOEM have worked jointly to add value and make available some of the most important historical records from the U.S. Coast Guard's national network of AIS receivers. This data set represents annual vessel transit counts summarized at a 100-meter by 100-meter geographic area. A single transit is counted each time a vessel track passes through, starts, or stops within a 100-meter grid cell.
source_data_citation: Office of Coast Survey, 2023: Shipping Fairways, Lanes, and Zones for US waters. NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information, https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/inport/item/39986.
layer_methodology: The GRIDCERF suitability layer excludes the following areas in the dataset: Shipping Fairways Lanes and Zones, Traffic Separation Schemes, Traffic Separateion Schemes/Traffic Lanes, and Recommended Routes. A 3 km buffer is applied to the composite areas. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Offshore Submarine Cable Areas
source_data_title: Submarine Cable Areas
source_data_description: These data show the general location of commercial and research submarine cables within U.S. waters. The majority of these cables are for telecommunications, and the remaining are for power transmission. The geographic footprint for each cable may vary and is dependent on the original source data. In the near shore, cables are routinely buried below the seabed. Offshore, they are placed directly on the seabed. A submarine cable area may contain one or more physical cables, and 30 CFR 585.301 defines a minimum 100-foot-wide right of way grant on each side of a cable.
source_data_citation: Office for Coastal Management, 2023: Submarine Cable Areas. NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information, https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/inport/item/66190.
layer_methodology: All submarine cable areas are included in the composite raster. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Offshore Wrecks and Obstructions
source_data_title: Wrecks and Obstructions
source_data_description: Shipwrecks and obstructions in the ocean have long been a hazard to navigation and construction, and points of interest to archaeologists, recreational divers, fishermen, educators, and explorers. Locating hazardous wrecks and obstructions is part of the ongoing NOAA charting process. The exact position of many wrecks is difficult to determine because of changes in the environment, varied survey methods, and human error. Some wrecks are intentionally placed in the ocean to serve as artificial reefs or for disposal. Others pose a health and environmental threat from their cargo. Ownership and control over wrecks and obstructions is governed by a collection of state and federal regulations, the Abandoned Shipwreck Act, National Historic Preservation Act, and National Marine Sanctuaries Act.
source_data_citation: Office for Coastal Management, 2023: Wrecks and Obstructions. NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information, https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/inport/item/70439.
layer_methodology: All areas in the dataset are included in the compiled suitability layer. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003)coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Densely Populated Areas, SSP2 2020
source_data_title: Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
source_data_description: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
source_data_citation: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756179
layer_methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. Any 25-square mile circle and all inclusive area is considered unsuitable for siting (value=1) if the population within that circular area is greater than or equal to 50,000 people.

data_layer_methodology_check: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas in 5 year increments between 2025 and 2100, inclusive for SSP2, SSP3, and SSP5. source_data_citation: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756201
layer_methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. Any 25-square mile circle and all inclusive area is considered unsuitable for siting (value=1) if the population within that circular area is greater than or equal to 50,000 people.
source_data_title_check: Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.

source_data_citation_check: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756179
data_layer_methodology_check: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas in 5 year increments between 2025 and 2100, inclusive for SSP2, SSP3, and SSP5. Three types of population density suitability layers are created for each year/SSP combination: (1) densely populated areas are excluded with no additional buffer, (2) densely populated areas + a 25 mile buffer, and (3) a nuclear-technology specific suitability.

source_data_citation_check: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756179
data_layer_methodology_check: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas in 5 year increments between 2025 and 2100, inclusive for SSP2, SSP3, and SSP5. Three types of population density suitability layers are created for each year/SSP combination: (1) densely populated areas are excluded with no additional buffer, (2) densely populated areas + a 25 mile buffer, and (3) a nuclear-technology specific suitability.

layer_methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. Any 25-square mile circle, all inclusive area is considered unsuitable for siting (value=1) if the population within the circular area is greater than or equal to 50,000 people. All area within 25 miles of unsuitable areas is also considered unsuitable for siting.

data_layer_methodology_check: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas in 5 year increments between 2025 and 2100, inclusive for SSP2, SSP3, and SSP5. Three types of population density suitability layers are created for each year/SSP combination: (1) densely populated areas are excluded with no additional buffer, (2) densely populated areas + a 25 mile buffer, and (3) a nuclear-technology specific suitability.

layer_methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. All area within 25 miles of unsuitable areas is also considered unsuitable for siting.

data_layer_methodology_check: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas in 5 year increments between 2025 and 2100, inclusive for SSP2, SSP3, and SSP5. Three types of population density suitability layers are created for each year/SSP combination: (1) densely populated areas are excluded with no additional buffer, (2) densely populated areas + a 25 mile buffer, and (3) a nuclear-technology specific suitability.

plain_language_layer_name: Densely Populated Areas  - nuclear specific SSP2 2020
source_data_title: Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
source_data_description: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
source_data_citation: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756281
layer_methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. Siting nuclear reactors requires specific population-density based metrics. Using a singular grid-cell as a starting point, any circle drawn around that point, up to a 20-mile radius, is excluded as unsuitable if the average population density within that circle is greater than or equal to 500 people per square mile. To avoid offshore areas with population of 0 decreasing the average for coastal areas, offshore areas are considered to have null population and are not included in the average for any circle that includes offshore areas.

source_data_citation_check: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756179
data_layer_methodology_check: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas in 5 year increments between 2025 and 2100, inclusive for SSP2, SSP3, and SSP5. Three types of population density suitability layers are created for each year/SSP combination: (1) densely populated areas are excluded with no additional buffer, (2) densely populated areas + a 25 mile buffer, and (3) a nuclear-technology specific suitability.

plain_language_layer_name: Densely Populated Areas  - nuclear specific SSP2 2030
source_data_title: Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
source_data_description: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.
source_data_citation: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756283
layer_methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. Siting nuclear reactors requires specific population-density based metrics. Using a singular grid-cell as a starting point, any circle drawn around that point, up to a 20-mile radius, is excluded as unsuitable if the average population density within that circle is greater than or equal to 500 people per square mile. To avoid offshore areas with population of 0 decreasing the average for coastal areas, offshore areas are considered to have null population and are not included in the average for any circle that includes offshore areas.

source_data_title: Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways.

layer_methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. Siting nuclear reactors requires specific population-density based metrics. Using a singular grid-cell as a starting point, any circle drawn around that point, up to a 20-mile radius, is excluded as unsuitable if the average population density within that circle is greater than or equal to 500 people per square mile. To avoid offshore areas with population of 0 decreasing the average for coastal areas, offshore areas are considered to have null population and are not included in the average for any circle that includes offshore areas.

data_layer_methodology_check: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas in 5 year increments between 2025 and 2100, inclusive for SSP2, SSP3, and SSP5. Three types of population density suitability layers are created for each year/SSP combination: (1) densely populated areas are excluded with no additional buffer, (2) densely populated areas + a 25 mile buffer, and (3) a nuclear-technology specific suitability.

source_data_citation: Zoraghein, H., & O'Neill, B. (2020). Data Supplement: U.S. state-level projections of the spatial distribution of population consistent with Shared Socioeconomic Pathways. (v0.1.0) [Data set]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3756312
layer_methodology: Suitability layers are created for densely populated areas for the indicated socioeconomic pathway and year combination. Siting nuclear reactors requires specific population-density based metrics. Using a singular grid-cell as a starting point, any circle drawn around that point, up to a 20-mile radius, is excluded as unsuitable if the average population density within that circle is greater than or equal to 500 people per square mile. To avoid offshore areas with population of 0 decreasing the average for coastal areas, offshore areas are considered to have null population and are not included in the average for any circle that includes offshore areas.

plain_language_layer_name: Proximity to Transportation Infrastructure (Rail Nodes and Navigable Waters)
source_data_title: U.S. Department of Transportation (USDOT) Bureau of Transportation Statistics (BTS) North American Rail Network Nodes
source_data_description: The rail nodes dataset supports the topology of the North American Rail Network (NARN) and attributes information for use in network analysis applications. The North American Rail Network (NARN) Rail Nodes dataset was created in 2016 and was updated on July 14, 2023 from the Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) and is part of the U.S. Department of Transportation (USDOT)/Bureau of Transportation Statistics (BTS) National Transportation Atlas Database (NTAD). The NARN Rail Nodes dataset is a database of North America's railway system at 1:24,000 or better within the United States. The data set covers all 50 States, the District of Columbia, Mexico, and Canada. The dataset holds topology of the network and provides geographic location information.
source_data_citation: U.S. Department of Transportation. North American Rail Network Nodes. U.S. Department of Transportation https://data-usdot.opendata.arcgis.com/datasets/usdot::north-american-rail-network-nodes/explore?location=34.085743%2C-108.310932%2C3.96 (2023).
layer_methodology: All source datasets are reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system. Areas are considered suitable if they are (1) within 5 km of a US rail line (data source 1), or (2) within 5 km of a US navigable waterway (data source 2). The combination of these conditions sets the composite suitability for this layer.
source_data_title_check: U.S. Department of Transportation (USDOT) Bureau of Transportation Statistics (BTS) North American Rail Network Nodes

plain_language_layer_name: Proximity to Transportation Infrastructure (Rail Nodes and Navigable Waters)
source_data_title: U.S. Department of Transportation (USDOT) Bureau of Transportation Statistics (BTS) Navigable Waterway Network Lines
source_data_description: The Navigable Waterway Network Lines dataset is periodically updated by the United States Army Corp of Engineers (USACE) and is part of the U.S. Department of Transportation (USDOT)/Bureau of Transportation Statistics (BTS) National Transportation Atlas Database (NTAD). The National Waterway Network (Lines) is a comprehensive network database of the Nation's navigable waterways. The dataset covers the 48 contiguous states plus the District of Columbia, Hawaii, Alaska, Puerto Rico and water links between. It consists of a line feature class of the National Waterway Network (NWN), which is based on a route feature class for the NWN update regions (“1” through “7”, as well as the open ocean region “0”) and route event table with linear referencing system measures for NWN links. This dataset is a feature class with associated measures (in miles) that are used for finding distances, locating features, and displaying route event layers. It was exported from this route event layer. The nominal scale of the dataset varies with the source material. The majority of the information is at 1:100,000 with larger scales used in harbor/bay/port areas and smaller scales used in open waters. These data could be used for analytical studies of waterway performance, for compiling commodity flow statistics, and for mapping purposes.
source_data_citation: U.S. Department of Transportation. Navigable Waterway Network Lines. Bureau of Transportation Statistics https://geodata.bts.gov/datasets/usdot::navigable-waterway-network-lines/about (2023).
layer_methodology: All source datasets are reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system. Areas are considered suitable if they are (1) within 5 km of a US rail line (data source 1), or (2) within 5 km of a US navigable waterway (data source 2). The combination of these conditions sets the composite suitability for this layer.

plain_language_layer_name: Proximity to Seawater, 20 mile buffer
source_data_title: 2022 TIGER/Line® Shapefiles: Coastline
source_data_description: The 2022 TIGER/Line Shapefiles contain current geographic extent and boundaries of both legal and statistical entities (which have no governmental standing) for the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the Island areas. This vintage includes boundaries of governmental units that match the data from the surveys that use 2022 geography (e.g., the 2022 American Community Survey).
source_data_citation: US Census Bureau, 2022. TIGER/Line Shapefiles: Coastline. Geography Division, U.S. Census Bureau, https://www2.census.gov/geo/tiger/TIGER2022/COASTLINE/tl_2022_us_coastline.zip
layer_methodology: All land areas within 20 miles of the coastline are used to create the seawater cooling suitability layer. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Exclude Areas with Slope Greater than 5%
source_data_title: SRTM Digital Elevation Data Version 4
source_data_description: The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) digital elevation dataset was originally produced to provide consistent, high-quality elevation data at near global scope. This version of the SRTM digital elevation data has been processed to fill data voids, and to facilitate its ease of use.
source_data_citation: Jarvis, A., Reuter, H. I., Nelson, A. & Guevara, E., 2008. Hole-filled SRTM for the globe Version 4. CGIAR Consortium for Spatial Information https://research.utwente.nl/en/publications/hole-filled-srtm-for-the-globe-version-4-data-grid (accessed 10/31/22).
layer_methodology: All land areas with slope greater than the specified percentage are considered unsuitable. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Concentrating Solar Power (CSP) Potential, 20% Capacity Factor or Greater
source_data_title: Concentrating Solar Direct Normal Potential
source_data_description: Monthly and annual average direct normal irradiance for Hawaii and the contiguous United States
source_data_citation: Perez, R. et al. A new operational model for satellite-derived irradiances: description and validation. Solar Energy 73, 307-317 (2002).
layer_methodology: The suitability layers for Concentrating Solar Power (CSP) potential correspond to areas capable of meeting a specified capacity factor on an annual average basis. Areas with suitable direct normal irradiance levels to meet the capacity factor are considered suitable. It is assumed that CSP plants are paired with energy storage which meets half of their required capacity factor. The required irradiance level corresponds to the (.5 * AC CapacityFactor * 24). The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Solar Photovoltaic (PV) Potential, 4% Capacity Factor or Greater
source_data_title: Photovoltaic Potential
source_data_description: Monthly and annual average global horizontal irradiance for Hawaii and the contiguous United States.
source_data_citation: Perez, R. et al. A new operational model for satellite-derived irradiances: description and validation. Solar Energy 73, 307-317 (2002).
layer_methodology: The suitability layers for solar photovoltaic potential correspond to areas capable of meeting a specified capacity factor on an annual average basis. Areas with suitable global horizontal irradiance levels to meet the capacity factor are considered suitable. The required irradiance level corresponds to the (DC CapacityFactor * 24)/(InverterEfficiency * Derate). The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: State-level Geothermal Exclusions
source_data_title: Protected Areas Exclusion (Geothermal)
source_data_description: Protected Areas Exclusions are areas in California, identified by California Energy Commission staff as legally protected from geothermal development and excluded from geothermal resource potential calculation in the draft SB100 land-use screen project. A combination of statewide geospatial datasets was combined to create the Protected Areas Exclusion.
source_data_citation: California Energy Commission, 2023. Protected Areas Exclusion (Geothermal).https://data.cnra.ca.gov/dataset/protected-areas-exclusion-geothermal/resource/3931dea5-45e6-4bd2-a5bc-bce8ff18616e (accessed 10/11/23)
layer_methodology: The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: State-level Solar Exclusions
source_data_title: Protected Areas Exclusion (Solar)
source_data_description: The protected area layer is a composite GIS layer designed to encompass areas where utility-scale renewable energy or transmission development is precluded by state or federal law, policy, or regulation. It draws from several protected areas datasets, local, state or federal land that is designated for other uses, easements, and other similar designations. The protected area layer is combined with the techno-economic exclusion layer to form the base exclusions in the CEC 2023 Land Use Screens.
source_data_citation: California Energy Commission, 2023. Protected Areas Exclusion (Solar).https://data.cnra.ca.gov/dataset/protected-areas-exclusion-solar (accessed 10/11/23)
layer_methodology: The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: State-level Wind Exclusions
source_data_title: Protected Areas Exclusion (Wind)
source_data_description: Protected Areas Exclusions are areas in California, identified by California Energy Commission staff as legally protected from geothermal development and excluded from geothermal resource potential calculation in the draft SB100 land-use screen project. A combination of statewide geospatial datasets was combined to create the Protected Areas Exclusion.
source_data_citation: California Energy Commission, 2023. Protected Areas Exclusion (Wind).https://data.cnra.ca.gov/dataset/protected-areas-exclusion-geothermal/resource/3931dea5-45e6-4bd2-a5bc-bce8ff18616e (accessed 10/11/23)
layer_methodology: The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system prior to rasterization, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Weather Radar Stations, 5 Mile Buffer
source_data_title: Weather Radar Stations
source_data_description: These data represent Next-Generation Radar (NEXRAD) and Terminal Doppler Weather Radar (TDWR) weather radar stations within the US. The NEXRAD radar stations are maintained and operated by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The TDWR radar stations are maintained and operated by the Federal Aviation Administration.
source_data_citation: Office for Coastal Management, 2023: Weather Radar Stations, https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/inport/item/48940 (accessed 09/25/23).
layer_methodology: Weather radar points included in the source data + a buffer of 5 miles are considered unsuitable areas. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Onshore Wind 80m Hub Height, No Resource Potential
source_data_title: Wind Speed (100m Annual Average)
source_data_description: Depicts mean annual wind speed at a height of 100 meters, gridded at a spatial resolution of 2,000 meters.
source_data_citation: Draxl, C., Clifton, A., Hodge, B.-M. & McCaa, J. The Wind Integration National Dataset (WIND) Toolkit. Applied Energy 151, 355-366 (2015).
layer_methodology: The 100m annnual average wind speed data contains raster data (data source 1) for average wind speeds at 10m, 40m, 60m, 80m, 100m, 120m, 140m, 160m, and 200m for both onshore and offshore areas. To align with current and future utility scale wind farms, only 80m and above data is used.  For areas indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Onshore Wind 80m Hub Height Resource Potential, 5% Capacity Factor or Greater
source_data_title: Wind Speed (100m Annual Average)
source_data_description: Depicts mean annual wind speed at a height of 100 meters, gridded at a spatial resolution of 2,000 meters.
source_data_citation: Draxl, C., Clifton, A., Hodge, B.-M. & McCaa, J. The Wind Integration National Dataset (WIND) Toolkit. Applied Energy 151, 355-366 (2015).
layer_methodology: The 100m annnual average wind speed data contains raster data (data source 1) for average wind speeds at 10m, 40m, 60m, 80m, 100m, 120m, 140m, 160m, and 200m for both onshore and offshore areas. To align with current and future utility scale wind farms, only 80m and above data is used. To determine which areas are capable of meeting specific capacity factors for wind generation, the wind power density at the wind turbine rotor elevation must be calculated. Wind power is equal to the turbine efficiency rating * air density * rotor area * wind speed^3 (see, https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc297/node/649). Air density varies based on altitude. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Onshore Wind 80m Hub Height Resource Potential, 40% Capacity Factor or Greater
source_data_title: Wind Speed (100m Annual Average)
source_data_description: Depicts mean annual wind speed at a height of 100 meters, gridded at a spatial resolution of 2,000 meters.
source_data_citation: Draxl, C., Clifton, A., Hodge, B.-M. & McCaa, J. The Wind Integration National Dataset (WIND) Toolkit. Applied Energy 151, 355-366 (2015).
layer_methodology: The 100m annnual average wind speed data contains raster data (data source 1) for average wind speeds at 10m, 40m, 60m, 80m, 100m, 120m, 140m, 160m, and 200m for both onshore and offshore areas. To align with current and future utility scale wind farms, only 80m and above data is used. To determine which areas are capable of meeting specific capacity factors for wind generation, the wind power density at the wind turbine rotor elevation must be calculated. Wind power is equal to the turbine efficiency rating * air density * rotor area * wind speed^3 (see, https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc297/node/649). Air density varies based on altitude. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

source_data_description: Depicts mean annual wind speed at a height of 100 meters, gridded at a spatial resolution of 2,000 meters.
source_data_citation: Draxl, C., Clifton, A., Hodge, B.-M. & McCaa, J. The Wind Integration National Dataset (WIND) Toolkit. Applied Energy 151, 355-366 (2015).
layer_methodology: The 100m annnual average wind speed data contains raster data (data source 1) for average wind speeds at 10m, 40m, 60m, 80m, 100m, 120m, 140m, 160m, and 200m for both onshore and offshore areas. To align with current and future utility scale wind farms, only 80m and above data is used. To determine which areas are capable of meeting specific capacity factors for wind generation, the wind power density at the wind turbine rotor elevation must be calculated. Wind power is equal to the turbine efficiency rating * air density * rotor area * wind speed^3 (see, https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc297/node/649). Air density varies based on altitude. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

source_data_description: Depicts mean annual wind speed at a height of 100 meters, gridded at a spatial resolution of 2,000 meters.
source_data_citation: Draxl, C., Clifton, A., Hodge, B.-M. & McCaa, J. The Wind Integration National Dataset (WIND) Toolkit. Applied Energy 151, 355-366 (2015).
layer_methodology: The 100m annnual average wind speed data contains raster data (data source 1) for average wind speeds at 10m, 40m, 60m, 80m, 100m, 120m, 140m, 160m, and 200m for both onshore and offshore areas. To align with current and future utility scale wind farms, only 80m and above data is used. To determine which areas are capable of meeting specific capacity factors for wind generation, the wind power density at the wind turbine rotor elevation must be calculated. Wind power is equal to the turbine efficiency rating * air density * rotor area * wind speed^3 (see, https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc297/node/649). Air density varies based on altitude. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

source_data_description: Depicts mean annual wind speed at a height of 100 meters, gridded at a spatial resolution of 2,000 meters.
source_data_citation: Draxl, C., Clifton, A., Hodge, B.-M. & McCaa, J. The Wind Integration National Dataset (WIND) Toolkit. Applied Energy 151, 355-366 (2015).
layer_methodology: The 100m annnual average wind speed data contains raster data (data source 1) for average wind speeds at 10m, 40m, 60m, 80m, 100m, 120m, 140m, 160m, and 200m for both onshore and offshore areas. To align with current and future utility scale wind farms, only 80m and above data is used. To determine which areas are capable of meeting specific capacity factors for wind generation, the wind power density at the wind turbine rotor elevation must be calculated. Wind power is equal to the turbine efficiency rating * air density * rotor area * wind speed^3 (see, https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc297/node/649). Air density varies based on altitude. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Onshore Wind 80m Hub Height Resource Potential, 5% Capacity Factor or Greater
source_data_title: 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States
source_data_description: This layer is a georeferenced raster image displaying elevation data for the conterminous United States. These data were derived from the National Elevation Dataset (NED) released in October, 2012, The elevation data shows the terrain at a resolution of 100 meters. The NED is a raster product assembled by the U.S. Geological Survey, designed to provide national elevation data in a seamless form with a consistent datum, elevation unit, and projection.
source_data_citation: National Atlas of the United States, 2012. 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States. National Atlas of the United States. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/zz186ss2071.

plain_language_layer_name: Onshore Wind 100m Hub Height Resource Potential, 20% Capacity Factor or Greater
source_data_title: 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States
source_data_description: This layer is a georeferenced raster image displaying elevation data for the conterminous United States. These data were derived from the National Elevation Dataset (NED) released in October, 2012, The elevation data shows the terrain at a resolution of 100 meters. The NED is a raster product assembled by the U.S. Geological Survey, designed to provide national elevation data in a seamless form with a consistent datum, elevation unit, and projection.
source_data_citation: National Atlas of the United States, 2012. 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States. National Atlas of the United States. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/zz186ss2071.
layer_methodology: The 100m annnual average wind speed data contains raster data (data source 1) for average wind speeds at 10m, 40m, 60m, 80m, 100m, 120m, 140m, 160m, and 200m for both onshore and offshore areas. To align with current and future utility scale wind farms, only 80m and above data is used. To determine which areas are capable of meeting specific capacity factors for wind generation, the wind power density at the wind turbine rotor elevation must be calculated. Wind power is equal to the turbine efficiency rating * air density * rotor area * wind speed^3 (see, https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc297/node/649). Air density varies based on altitude. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

source_data_citation: National Atlas of the United States, 2012. 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States. National Atlas of the United States. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/zz186ss2071.
layer_methodology: The 100m annnual average wind speed data contains raster data (data source 1) for average wind speeds at 10m, 40m, 60m, 80m, 100m, 120m, 140m, 160m, and 200m for both onshore and offshore areas. To align with current and future utility scale wind farms, only 80m and above data is used. To determine which areas are capable of meeting specific capacity factors for wind generation, the wind power density at the wind turbine rotor elevation must be calculated. Wind power is equal to the turbine efficiency rating * air density * rotor area * wind speed^3 (see, https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc297/node/649). Air density varies based on altitude. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Onshore Wind 100m Hub Height Resource Potential, 40% Capacity Factor or Greater
source_data_title: 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States
source_data_description: This layer is a georeferenced raster image displaying elevation data for the conterminous United States. These data were derived from the National Elevation Dataset (NED) released in October, 2012, The elevation data shows the terrain at a resolution of 100 meters. The NED is a raster product assembled by the U.S. Geological Survey, designed to provide national elevation data in a seamless form with a consistent datum, elevation unit, and projection.
source_data_citation: National Atlas of the United States, 2012. 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States. National Atlas of the United States. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/zz186ss2071.
layer_methodology: The 100m annnual average wind speed data contains raster data (data source 1) for average wind speeds at 10m, 40m, 60m, 80m, 100m, 120m, 140m, 160m, and 200m for both onshore and offshore areas. To align with current and future utility scale wind farms, only 80m and above data is used. To determine which areas are capable of meeting specific capacity factors for wind generation, the wind power density at the wind turbine rotor elevation must be calculated. Wind power is equal to the turbine efficiency rating * air density * rotor area * wind speed^3 (see, https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc297/node/649). Air density varies based on altitude. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

To determine which areas are capable of meeting specific capacity factors for wind generation, the wind power density at the wind turbine rotor elevation must be calculated. Wind power is equal to the turbine efficiency rating * air density * rotor area * wind speed^3 (see, https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc297/node/649). Air density varies based on altitude. To estimate the altitude at each location in the CONUS, the elevation at each point is used in conjunction with the hub height of the turbine being evaluated. Only areas capable of generating sufficient wind energy on average across an entire year are deemed suitable. For layers indicating no wind potential, all areas with average wind speed < 4m/s (wind cut-in speed) are excluded. The source data is reprojected to the NAD 1983 Albers contiguous USA (ESRI:102003) coordinate reference system, no other buffers or modifications are applied.

plain_language_layer_name: Onshore Wind 160m Hub Height Resource Potential, 35% Capacity Factor or Greater
source_data_title: 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States
source_data_description: This layer is a georeferenced raster image displaying elevation data for the conterminous United States. These data were derived from the National Elevation Dataset (NED) released in October, 2012, The elevation data shows the terrain at a resolution of 100 meters. The NED is a raster product assembled by the U.S. Geological Survey, designed to provide national elevation data in a seamless form with a consistent datum, elevation unit, and projection.
source_data_citation: National Atlas of the United States, 2012. 100-Meter Resolution Elevation of the Conterminous United States. National Atlas of the United States. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/zz186ss2071.
